deliberation: Considered whether the command is purely literal. Found (1) the vocative בֶן־אָדָם as an idiomatic/metonymic way to stress Ezekiel’s mortality, and (2) the brick with an incised city functioning as a symbolic substitute for Jerusalem, an enacted metaphor.

ontological contrast to God

instances.hebrew_text: קַח־לְךָ לְבֵנָה וְנָתַתָּה אוֹתָהּ לְפָנֶיךָ וְחַקּוֹתָ עָלֶיהָ עִיר אֶת־יְרוּשָׁלָ͏ִם

deliberation: All siege terminology is literal for the model, but in the prophetic context the constructed siege is a symbolic representation of the real Babylonian siege. Treated the whole complex instruction as one enacted metaphorical sign.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתָּה עָלֶיהָ מָצוֹר וּבָנִיתָ עָלֶיהָ דָּיֵק וְשָׁפַכְתָּ עָלֶיהָ סֹלְלָה וְנָתַתָּה עָלֶיהָ מַחֲנוֹת וְשִׂים־עָלֶיהָ כָּרִים סָבִיב

structure of encirclement and assault
analogy between model-siege and real siege

instances.explanation: The detailed siege of the brick is an enacted metaphor for the actual siege that will befall Jerusalem; the model warfare stands in for real warfare.

deliberation: Identified (1) the iron plate used as an ‘iron wall’ as a metaphorical barrier symbolizing separation, (2) ‘set your face against it’ as a standard Hebrew idiom for determined hostility, and (3) ‘house of Israel’ as a metonymic expression for the people.

instances.hebrew_text: קַח־לְךָ מַחֲבַת בַּרְזֶל וְנָתַתָּה אוֹתָהּ קִיר בַּרְזֶל בֵּינְךָ וּבֵין הָעִיר

part-whole and container-content relations

instances.explanation: ‘House of Israel’ is a metonymic/synecdochic way of referring to the people of Israel collectively, depicting them as members of a single house.

deliberation: The posture of lying on the left side is a literal part of the sign. The expressions ‘put the iniquity on it’ and ‘you shall bear their iniquity’ treat sin as a load placed on and carried by the prophet; together with ‘house of Israel’ this forms a composite metaphor/metonymy.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשַׂמְתָּ אֶת־עֲוֹן בֵּית־יִשְׂרָאֵל עָלָיו ... תִּשָּׂא אֶת־עֲוֹנָם

instances.explanation: The idiom ‘bear iniquity’ conceptualizes Israel’s sin and its consequences as a heavy load placed on the prophet, while ‘house of Israel’ metonymically denotes the people whose burden he carries.

deliberation: Again the text explains the duration of the sign. The key figurative element is the repeated idiom ‘you shall bear the iniquity of the house of Israel’, using the burden metaphor; the counting of days itself is literal specification of the sign’s length.

instances.english_text: and so you shall bear the punishment for the House of Israel

instances.explanation: The phrase again uses the metaphor of carrying a load to describe bearing the consequences of Israel’s sin, with ‘house of Israel’ as the metonymic designation of the people.

deliberation: Detected two figurative strands: (1) the continued ‘bear the iniquity of the house of Judah’ using the burden metaphor and metonymy, and (2) the formula ‘a day for a year’ where each day in the sign stands symbolically for an actual year, a time-compression metaphor.

instances.english_text: and bear the punishment of the House of Judah

burden as analogue for consequences of sin
moral weight imagined as physical weight
posture: Ezekiel enacts Judah’s burden before the audience
instances.explanation: ‘Bear the iniquity of the house of Judah’ repeats the burden metaphor for sin and uses ‘house of Judah’ metonymically for the people of Judah.

deliberation: Found two idiomatic/figurative body expressions: ‘set your face toward’ the siege as a metaphor for resolute opposition, and ‘with bared arm’ as a conventional image of exposed, ready strength (arm as synecdoche for power).

instances.english_text: set your face toward besieged Jerusalem

focused hostility and resolve
orientation of body mapping onto orientation of will

instances.explanation: The command to ‘set your face toward’ is an idiomatic metaphor for firm, hostile determination directed at Jerusalem.

deliberation: Considered whether the cords and ‘days of your siege’ are metaphorical, but here they describe the literal constraints of the enacted sign; no distinct idiom or metaphor beyond the broader sign-act was found in the wording itself.

The mixed ingredients and single vessel form a symbolic picture of scarcity and poor-quality bread, but the verse’s language is straightforward instruction without a discrete metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond the enacted symbolism.
The rationing of food ‘by weight’ is symbolically important but linguistically literal; no metaphorical or idiomatic expressions occur in this verse apart from that broader sign significance.
As in v.10, the measuring of water describes literal quantities within the sign-act. I found no independent metaphor, simile, or idiom in the Hebrew phrasing itself.

The instruction is literal for the sign, yet v.13 explicitly interprets it as symbolizing impure bread among the nations. Thus the act of baking bread on human excrement functions as an enacted metaphor of defilement.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִיא בְּגֶלְלֵי צֵאַת הָאָדָם תְּעֻגֶנָּה לְעֵינֵיהֶם

instances.explanation: Baking bread on human excrement is an enacted metaphor for the defiled, polluted nature of Israel’s sustenance among the nations.

deliberation: The verse interprets the sign and centralizes ‘their bread impure among the nations’. Here ‘bread’ stands metonymically for all sustenance and daily life, and the image of eating impure bread metaphorically depicts the degraded, defiled condition of exile.

instances.hebrew_text: כָּכָה יֹאכְלוּ בְנֵי־יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶת־לַחְמָם טָמֵא בַּגּוֹיִם

deliberation: Most of the verse lists literal food-law categories. The phrase ‘my soul has not been defiled’ uses נַפְשִׁי (my soul) metonymically for the whole person/self, a common anthropological figure in Biblical Hebrew.

instances.english_text: my person was never defiled (lit. my soul has not been defiled)

instances.explanation: By saying ‘my soul has not been defiled’, Ezekiel uses ‘soul’ as a metonym for his whole person, expressing complete personal purity.

deliberation: The substitution of cow’s dung for human excrement modifies the sign but is expressed literally. No separate metaphor, idiom, or other standard figure emerges in the wording beyond the already interpreted symbolism of vv.12–13.

Identified ‘I am going to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem’ as a well-known Hebrew metaphor/idiom: bread is pictured as a staff that supports life. ‘Bread’ further functions metonymically for the whole food supply.

deliberation: The lack of bread and water is literal. The clause ‘they shall waste away in their iniquity’ uses physical decay (wasting away) as a metaphor for the destructive effect of sin, portraying iniquity as a kind of consuming disease.

instances.explanation: ‘Waste away in their iniquity’ is a metaphor that likens the effects of sin to a wasting disease that causes progressive physical decay.
